tsn: Kwa tshimologong, re lebeletse gore lefelo le bogolo jo bo kana kang gore re kgone go rulaganya lenaneo la rona, mme morago ra sekaseka thulaganyo ya boagi jwa lebota la letlapa.

en: To record the site, maps were produced using a combination of handheld GPSs and a Trimble Station; these use satellites to record geo-specific points that can be rendered digitally to resemble the settlement’s structure and features.
tsn: Go rekota lefelo, dimmepe di ne tsa tlhagisiwa ka go dirisa kopantsho ya GPS e e tshwarwang ka letsogo le seteišene sa trimble; dilo tse di dirisa sathalaete go rekota mafelo a a rileng a a ka dirisang tsa dijithale go senola  diponagalo tsa kagego ya bonno.

en: An enclosure inside the western settlement likely used as a kraal for livestock.
tsn: Lefelo le le mo teng ga bonno jwa sešweng jo bo ka tswa bo dirisiwa jaaka lesaka la diruiwa.

en: Mapping the site is informative; as building designs today differ between people and over time, so did past stone-walled structures.
tsn: Go dira mmapa wa lefelo go neelana ka tshedimosetso ka ntlha ya gore ditsela tsa go dira dilo gompieno di farologana go ya ka batho le go ya ka nako, fela jalo le ka dikago tsa matlapa tsa mo nakong e e fetileng.

en: By studying the layout of the settlement, we can then attempt to determine who occupied the site and when.
tsn: Ka go ithuta ka boalo jwa tulo e, re ka leka go tlhomamisa gore ke mang yo o neng a nna mo lefelong le, le nako e ba nnileng mo go lona ka yona.

en: Archaeologists have been doing this from the 1960s and there is a fairly good record of what the different types of sites look like.
tsn: Baithutamarope ba ntse ba dira seno go tloga ka dingwaga tsa bo 1960 mme go na le rekoto e e siameng ya mefuta e e farologaneng ya mafelo a a lebegang jalo.

en: By examining the structure of Driefontein, we could then match its architecture to typologies developed over the past 60 years and determine when it was occupied.
tsn: Ka go sekaseka popego ya Driefontein, re ka golaganya dikago tsa yona le mefuta e e  tlhamilweng mo dingwageng di le 60 tse di fetileng le go tlhomamisa gore batho ba nnile mo go tsona leng.

en: We can also infer the use of different areas of the site.
tsn: Gape re ka tsenyeletsa le tiriso ya dikarolo tse di farologaneng tsa lefelo.

en: There are other ways of doing this, such as through ceramic analysis or archaeological excavations, but at Driefontein very few items remain on the surface and there is no excavatable deposit.
tsn: Go na le ditsela tse dingwe tsa go dira se, jaaka ka tshekatsheko ya boalo kgotsa diphatololo tsa dilo tsa bogologolo, mme kwa Driefontein ke dilo di le mmalwa fela tse di salang mo godimo ga mmu mme ga go na sepe se se ka epololwang.

en: However, two middens were identified.
tsn: Le gale, mekoa e mebedi ya boloko e supilwe.

en: These were used as dump sites and often contain valuable archaeological material such as ceramic sherds, food waste, and personal ornaments.
tsn: Tseno di ne di dirisiwa jaaka mafelo a go latlhela matlakala mme go le gantsi a tshwere thuto e e botlhokwa jaaka boalo, leswe la dijo le mekgabisa ya batho.

en: Unfortunately, at Driefontein this was not the case; this meant that studying the walls layout was the only viable way of learning more about the history of the site.
tsn: Ka bomadimabe, kwa Driefontein se se ne se se jalo; Se se raya gore go ithuta ka boalo jwa dipota e ne e le yone fela tsela ya go ithuta go le gontsi ka ga hisetori ya lefelo.

en: Driefontein includes two distinct areas; what we call west and east.
tsn: Driefontein e akaretsa mafelo a mabedi a a farologaneng; Se re se bitsang Bophirima le Botlhaba.

en: Both have large circular structures outside the main walled area.
tsn: Bobedi jwa tsona bo na le sepopego se se sediko kwa ntle ga lefelo le le dikagenyeditsweng ke dipota.

en: These may have been kraals (enclosures) for livestock.
tsn: Tseno e ka tswa e ne e le masaka a (ditswalo) a diruiwa.

en: The main portions of the two areas both have an internal walled area with separate smaller enclosures attached.
tsn: Dikarolo tse dikgolo tsa mafelo a mabedi a di na le mafelo a a ka fa gare a a dikagenyeditsweng ke dipota le ditswalo tse di nnye tse di aroganeng.

en: Around this is a discontinuous and scalloping boundary wall.
tsn: Mo tikologong eno go na le diphatlha le lebota le le dirang molelwane wa scalloping.

en: Between it and the inner enclosure are up to 20 individual huts, including several with outside terraces.
tsn: Fa gare ga lefelo le, go na le matlo a bojang a ka nna 20, go akaretsa a le mmalwa a a nang le legora la kwa ntle.

en: These are indicated by upright rocks erected in a circular shape with extensions where terraces exist.
tsn: Tse, di supiwa ka matlapa a a emeletseng, a a agilweng ka sebopego se se sediko, le dikatoloso mo go nang le legora teng.

en: There are also grain bin foundations in the vicinity of several huts, which are similar in construction to the huts but are far smaller.
tsn: Go na gape le metheo ya dithoro mo tikologong ya matlo a bojang a le mmalwa, tse di agilweng go tshwana le matlo a bojang, fela tsona ke tse dinnye thata.

en: Upright rocks indicate the presence of a hut, since disappeared, with this one possessing a front terrace.
tsn: Matlapa a a emeletseng a supa go nna teng ga ntlo ya bojang, fa e sale a nyelela, fa e yona na le legora la kwa pele.

en: Based on the evidence, as well as the middens and a small collection of earthenware ceramics, the Driefontein stone-walled structure was a residential area.
tsn: Go ikaegilwe ka bopaki, gammogo le mekoa ya boloko le kokoanyo e nnye ya matsoapa, kago ya lebota la matlapa ya kwa Driefontein e ne e le lefelo la baagi.

en: The structure appears similar to settlements dating to between AD 1450 and 1700.
tsn: Kago e, e tshwana  le mafelo a a neng a le teng magareng ga  AD 1450 le 1700.

en: However, certain features  notably the upright rocks around the huts and lintels in the outside circular structures  have been identified at sites with a later date.
tsn: Le fa go le jalo, diponagalo tse dingwe, segololobogolo matlapa a a a emeletseng go dikologa matlo a bojang le mephako e e mo dikagong tse di kwa ntle tse di sediko di supilwe kwa mafelong ao, ka letlha le le kwa morago.

en: This possibly suggests that Driefontein is younger than we may expect.
tsn: Seno se ka tswa se kaya gore Driefontein e nnye go feta ka mokgwa o re neng re solofetse ka ona.

en: Though the settlements occupation falls within the Tswana period, naming the occupants as Tswana is complicated.
tsn: Le fa tseo ya mafelo a e wela mo nakong ya Batswana, go bitsa batho ba nnang mo tulong e re re ke Batswana, go marara.

en: That’s because Tswana history is not linear or direct.
tsn: Se ke ka ntlha ya gore hisetori ya Batswana ga e a tlhamalala.

en: Rather, there are periods of migration, political growth, and assimilation.
tsn: Go na le moo, go na le dinako tsa phudugo, kgolo ya sepolotiki le go itlwaetsa.

en: Tswana origins are also unclear
tsn: Tlholego ya Batswana le yona ga e a tlhapa sentle.

en: At times, oral histories note multiple lineages and totems with several different groups appearing and blending with others.
tsn: Ka dinako tse dingwe, dihisetori tsa molomo di ela tlhoko masika a le mantsi le merafe e e nang le ditlhopha tse di farologaneng di le mmalwa tse di tlhagelelang le go itlhakanya le ba bangwe.

en: When looking back at early archaeological sequences, such as may be the case at Driefontein, identifying Tswana groups is, for these reasons, quite challenging.
tsn: Fa re lebelela kwa morago ka tatelano ya thuto ya marope, jaaka go ka nna jalo kwa Driefontein, go supa ditlhopha tsa Batswana, ka ntlha ya mabaka a, go ne go le thata.

en: Nonetheless, based on the evidence, we believe Driefontein was likely occupied by Tswana-like groups after about AD 1450.
tsn: Le fa go ntse jalo, go ikaegilwe ka bopaki, re dumela gore Driefontein e ka tswa e ne e na le ditlhopha tsa batho, tse di tshwanang le Batswana, ba ba neng ba dula koo morago ga AD 1450.

en: This project was done with the involvement of the current landowners of the Nirox Sculpture Park and Project 58, where the site is located.
tsn: Porojeke eno e ne ya dirwa go akareditswe beng ba lefatshe ba jaana ba Nirox Sculpture Park le Project 58, kwa lefelo le le leng kwa teng.

en: Their interest in the site and openness to researchers is what ultimately led to us learning more of the region’s prehistory.
tsn: Kgatlhego e ba nang le yona mo lefelong le go letla babatlisisi go dira dipatlisiso, ke gona go dirileng gore kwa bofelong re kgone go ithuta go le gontsi ka hisetori ya dikgaolo tse.

en: Our work is far from over
tsn: Tiro ya rona e sale kgakala le go fela.

en: Future studies at Driefontein will help to further acknowledge more recent complex histories, identities and pasts that overlay the deep-time sequences preserved in the Cradle of Humankinds cave systems. Tim Forssman, Senior lecturer, University of Pretoria.
tsn: Dithuto tsa mo isagweng kwa Driefontein di tlaa thusa go tswelela go amogela dihisetori tsa bošeng jaana, boitshupo le dilo tse di fetileng tse di bontshang tatelano e e tseneletseng ya nako, tse di bolokilweng kwa logageng lwa Cradle of Humankind. Tim Forssman, Motlhatlheledi-mogolo, Yunibesiti ya Pretoria.

en: The community of New Brighton in Gqeberha in the Eastern Cape has launched an art project to skill youngsters and also keep them off the streets.
tsn: Baagi ba  New Brighton kwa Gqeberha kwa kgaolong ya Kapabophirima ba thangkgolotse porokeje ya botaki go neelana ka  bokgoni go bašwa le go ba tlosa mo mebileng.

en: The area used to be a tourist hub and the community is hoping the new project will help boost that sector in the Red Location area.
tsn: Lefelo le, le ne le  dirisiwa jaaka lefelo la go ngoka bajanala mme setšhaba se solofela gore porojeke e ntšhwa e tla thusa go tiisa gore lephata le mo lefelong la Red Location.

en: One of the children involved in the project, 12-year-old Mbali Mandlingosi says she loves being part of the project.
tsn: Mongwe wa bana ba ba nang le seabe mo porojekeng eno, Mbali Mandlingosi wa dingwaga di le 12, a re o rata go nna karolo ya porojeke.

en: I love drawing and painting
tsn: Ke rata go thala le go penta

en: I also come here on the weekend so I can meet my friends.
tsn: Gape ke tlaa kwano mo mafelong a beke gore ke kgone go kopana le ditsala tsa me.

en: The project has young artists showing their skills.
tsn: Porojeke e, e na le bataki ba bašwa ba ba bontshang bokgoni jwa bona.

en: Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge, on Sunday launched a book of photographic portraits taken during Britain’s COVID-19 lockdowns that she said would provide a lasting record of the pandemic.
tsn: Kate, Kgosatsana ya kwa Cambridge, ka Sontaga  o thangkgololotse buka  e e nang le ditshwantsho tse di tserweng ka nako ya kiletsometsao ka ntlha ya COVID-19 kwa Britain mme o tlaa tlamela ka rekoto ya leruri ya leroborobo.

en: Kate, who is married to Prince William, the Queens grandson and second in line to the throne, began the project with the National Portrait Gallery last year, inviting people to submit photos taken during Britain’s first coronavirus lockdown.
tsn: Kate, yo o nyetsweng ke Kgosana William, setlogolo sa kgosigadi, yo e leng ena wa bobedi mo go ba ba tlaa tsayang bogisi mo nakong e e tlang,  o simolotse porojeke e le ba kwa bobogelong jwa ditshwantsho jwa setšhaba mo ngwageng o o fetileng ka go laletsa batho go isa ditshwantsho tse di tswerweng ka nako ya kiletsometsamao ka ntlha ya COVID-19 kwa Britain.

en: A panel of judges including Kate chose 100 portraits from over 31,000 entries, which were shown in digital and community exhibitions before the book was announced.
tsn: Phanele ya baatlhodi go akaretsa Kate, ba tlhophile ditshwantsho di le 100 go tswa go di le 31,000 tse di neng di tsenetse kgaisano, tse di neng di bontshiwa mo go tsa dijithale le mo dipontshong tsa setšhaba pele go dirwa kitsiso ka ga buka e.

en: Still, I wanted to use the power of photography to create a lasting record of what we were all experiencing to capture individuals’ stories and document significant moments for families and communities as we lived through the pandemic, Kate wrote in the introduction to the book.
tsn: Ka jalo, ke ne ke batla go dirisa dithata tsa go tsaya ditshwantsho go tlhama rekoto e e tsweletseng ya se rotlhe re neng re itemogela sona go bontsha dikgang tsa batho le go gatisa ditiragalo tse di botlhokwa tsa malapa le baagi jaaka re ne re tshela mo nakong ya leroborobo, Kate o kwadile jalo mo kitsisong ya bukeng.

en: The book, called Hold Still: A Portrait of Our Nation in 2020, will be available from May 7, exactly a year after the project began.
tsn: Buka e, e e bidiwang Hold still: setshwantsho sa setšhaba sa rona ka ngwaga wa 2020, e tla nna teng go tloga ka di 7 Motsheganong, ngwaga morago ga porojeke e simolotse.

en: Net proceeds will be split between the National Portrait Gallery and the British mental health charity Mind.
tsn: Madi a a tlaa kgaoganngwa magareng ga bobogelo jwa ditshwantsho jwa bosetšhaba le ba boitekanelo jwa tlhaloganyo kwa Britain.

en: Music fans in Barcelona had rapid COVID-19 tests ahead of attending a rock concert on Saturday in a trial that, if successful, could provide a route to recovery for the ravaged live music industry in Spain and beyond.
tsn: Balatedi ba mmino kwa Barcelona ba tsere diteko tsa COVID-19 pele ba ya kwa konsarateng ya mmino wa Rock ka Lamatlhatso, mo tekong e e leng gore, fa e ka atlega, e tlaa tlamela ka pusetso ya intaseteri ya mmino e padimotsweng  kwa Spain le go feta.
